2022年是迎難而上的一年。

2022年伊始，全球經濟環境一片暗淡。新冠病毒變異株Omicron肆虐，令全球經濟增長繼續受壓，通脹壓力亦持續上升。其後俄羅斯與烏克蘭爆發衝突，進一步推高通脹壓力，導致各主要央行採取前置式貨幣緊縮政策，擴大環球金融市場的波動，並加劇經濟增長放緩的風險。本地方面，第五波疫情爆發，感染個案急速上升，亦進一步打擊經濟。同時，圍繞防疫措施與檢疫限制的負面報道，更令外界對香港產生誤解，威脅香港作為國際金融中心的聲譽。全年計，香港實質本地生產總值收縮了3.5%。

儘管面對重重挑戰，金管局繼續致力保障香港貨幣與金融穩定，並於主要策略範疇推進多項有利發展的措施，進一步鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位。經歷3年的旅遊限制後，我們成功向國際社會展示香港已全面復常，旅客亦能再次親身訪港體驗。金管局在去年11月舉辦「國際金融領袖投資峰會」，來自世界各地的金融領袖親身來港出席。外界如此熱烈的反應，成為印證香港全面復常最好不過的證明。

展望未來，外圍環境仍然充滿前所未有的不確定性。儘管如此，內地經濟重啟會為香港以至整個地區重新注入動力。金管局將繼續緊守崗位，履行維持香港貨幣與銀行體系穩定的職能，並積極尋求更多有利香港發展的機會，展現及提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。我們亦會繼續為提升全球氣候應變能力及可持續發展出力。今年除《二零二二年年報》外，我們會另外發表《二零二二年可持續發展報告》，以便更詳細地介紹金管局在提升香港作為綠色和可持續金融樞紐的地位所進行的各項工作，以及金管局作為負責任投資者及可持續機構所作出的努力。

# 貨幣及金融體系：堅穩如昔

聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）自1983年實施至今，歷經多個經濟周期，成功抵禦各種各樣的外來衝擊。2022年再次見證聯匯制度的抗震能力。在美國聯邦儲備局（聯儲局）大幅收緊貨幣政策下，弱方兌換保證於2022年5月至11月期間被觸發41次，金管局按照既定機制，以有序及具透明度的方式從市場買入合共2,421億港元。其間港元匯率及貨幣市場繼續運作暢順，反映聯匯制度穩健有效。

這份對聯匯制度的信心，來自於建立多年的穩固根基。正如國際貨幣基金組織在其《2022年對外部門報告》中重申，聯匯制度的公信力建基於多項因素，包括具高透明度的運作規則、充裕的外匯儲備、審慎的財政制度、穩健的金融監管，以及靈活的經濟結構。

我們深信除了穩健的機制外，致力與公眾及市場溝通以加深其對聯匯制度的了解、進行有效的市場監察，以及就不同情景作出應變計劃，均有助鞏固各界對聯匯制度的信心。我們就聯匯制度運作機制推出的社交媒體宣傳活動，有助在年內弱方兌換保證多次被觸發的情況下，有效維護市場對聯匯制度的信心。內部方面，金管局亦善用數據分析技術加強市場監察，讓我們能適時回應最新市場形勢。

年內，儘管面對宏觀層面的挑戰以及遞增的信用風險，香港銀行體系仍然維持穩健，資本及流動性均非常充裕。2022年底，本地銀行的綜合總資本充足比率為20.1%，遠高於國際最低要求的8%。2022年第4季，大型銀行的流動性覆蓋比率稍升至162.3%，亦遠高於法定最低要求的100%。鑑於信貸環境面對挑戰，銀行體系的資產質素略為轉差，特定分類貸款比率於2022年底升至1.38%，但有關水平仍屬穩健，並低於2000年以來的長期平均水平1.8%。

# 銀行體系：有效監管確保運作穩健

疫情持續3年，來自各方面的挑戰均有所加劇，例如地緣政治緊張局勢升溫及主要央行收緊貨幣政策。然而，全賴多年來妥善的風險管理及有效的監管，香港銀行體系得以維持穩健，繼續發揮支持經濟的重要作用。

過去一年面對的一項主要監管挑戰，是在第五波新冠疫情後經濟仍充滿不確定性之下，確保銀行繼續為客戶提供所需支援的同時，維持穩健的信用風險管理。「預先批核還息不還本」計劃進一步展期，並加入自願性部分本金還款選項，讓借款人可以選擇開始償還部分本金，協助客戶就最終回復正常還款作好準備。

因應主要經濟體大幅收緊貨幣政策令市場波動加劇，2022年金管局另一項主要監管工作是加強監察銀行的市場及流動性風險承擔。我們深入評估各經濟體同步收緊貨幣政策對銀行可能產生的影響，並就壓力測試引入新情景，以評估銀行應對長時間流動性壓力的韌性。

與此同時，我們繼續採取具前瞻性的措施，促進在多個範疇的有效風險管理。在運作穩健性及網絡防衛能力方面，我們提供指引協助銀行制定綜合及全面的運作架構，以達致穩健經營，並就銀行具體的運作範疇提供詳盡監管指引，例如因應雲端技術普及而就使用雲端運算提供指引。此外，因應數碼化加速發展，我們亦加強了應對「網絡釣魚」騙案和推進消費者及投資者保障的工作。

除了維持銀行體系穩健外，金管局亦致力推動普及金融及提高銀行服務的便利性。銀行對於金管局就提供基本銀行服務的呼籲反應正面，有銀行在新發展地區的大型公共屋邨增設分行及自助銀行服務設施。受到疫情相關的旅遊限制影響，許多香港市民無法使用其內地銀行戶口。有見及此，金管局與有關各方緊密合作，協助重新啓動約50萬個內地銀行戶口，受影響戶口持有人無需親身前往內地辦理。

另一個對銀行業持續發展具策略重要性的範疇是提升專業能力。為擴展業務，銀行業對專業人才的需求仍然龐大。金管局在其人才發展策略 — 「連接人才與未來」— 的基礎上，在過去一年推出多項措施，協助銀行業吸引、培育及挽留人才，集中提升及再培訓現有從業員的技能，以及培育年輕一代，以建立可持續的人才庫。

# 國際金融中心：香港重回國際舞台!

實施多時的疫情相關旅遊限制於2022年逐步撤銷，我們作出了多方面的努力讓香港重回國際舞台。11月舉行的「國際金融領袖投資峰會」吸引超過200位來自環球金融機構的國際及地區負責人親臨香港，並獲得全球各地的關注及熱切迴響。儘管峰會舉行日期不巧遇上50年來首個在11月份發出的8號颱風訊號，峰會仍然十分成功，向世界傳遞了香港已全面復常並正展現無比朝氣與活力的有力訊息。我們很高興看到峰會產生了正面的漣漪效應，不少環球金融機構及國際組織現正或計劃在香港舉辦各類活動。

除吸引各地訪客重臨香港外，我和金管局的同事體會到面對面交流聯繫的重要性，因此盡可能親身代表香港出席主要國際會議，積極參與全球政策討論，並藉外訪機會與環球金融機構的集團管理層會面，加深他們對香港穩健的金融體系以及在「一國兩制」下香港提供的各種機遇的了解。

為確保香港保持作為國際金融中心的競爭力，我們在金融科技、內地機遇，以及綠色和可持續金融等策略性重點領域不斷開拓市場新界限。我們亦進一步加強本港的金融平台，提供頂尖的服務，吸引更多企業落戶香港。有關金管局在綠色和可持續金融方面的工作詳情，請參閱《二零二二年可持續發展報告》。

# 金融科技

繼2021年6月公布「金融科技2025」策略，2022年我們在五大範疇均取得顯著進展。

我們在「全面推展銀行數碼化」方面的工作取得理想成果。根據金融科技應用評估的結果，香港銀行業在不同業務領域廣泛採用金融科技，而且所採用的科技類別亦持續增加。我們自2017年以來逐步推廣及支持數碼化的工作獲銀行積極回應，並持續取得成果，成續令人鼓舞。我們將繼續與業界緊密合作，根據評估的結果，進一步推動金融科技在特定銀行業務領域的應用及促進個別科技類別的發展。

年內我們在央行數碼貨幣方面的工作邁進重要的新里程。「多種央行數碼貨幣跨境網絡」(mBridge)項目進入試行階段，並成為全球其中一個率先為企業跨境交易進行真實結算的央行數碼貨幣項目。在零售層面，數字人民幣跨境使用的技術測試已進入第二階段，主要測試通過「轉數快」為數字人民幣錢包增值。數碼港元方面，我們將採取三軌道方式為將來可能發行數碼港元作好準備，並推出第二軌道先導計劃，邀請業界深入研究數碼港元可行的應用場景。

數據可全面釋放金融科技的潛力。我們於去年10月推出的「商業數據通」正是提升香港數據基建的重要一步。作為以數據擁有人授權為本的共享數據基建，「商業數據通」能方便金融機構提取企業的商業數據，使企業（尤其中小型企業）更容易獲得融資。截至2022年底，「商業數據通」已促成超過1,000宗中小企貸款，總額逾19億港元。

最後，我們在擁抱金融創新和它帶來的好處的同時，亦明白有必要監察及處理好相關發展可能帶來的風險。我們正密切注視虛擬資產領域的發展，並參與相關監管事宜的國際討論。經考慮公眾諮詢收集到的意見及相關國際標準後，我們將採納「相同風險，相同監管」1 的方式制定穩定幣的監管制度及界定其監管範圍。未來我們率先規管的對象將是那些標榜與一種或以上法定貨幣的價值掛鈎的穩定幣，因為這類穩定幣可能對貨幣及金融穩定帶來更高及更迫切的潛在風險。我們相信在訂立適當的規範下，業界將可更安全穩妥地開拓數碼金融的潛力。

科技正重塑我們的未來。金管局與銀行業界正積極準備迎向這個「新常態」。我們有信心我們正構建的金融科技生態圈將有助全面釋放金融科技的潛力，並提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。

# 內地機遇
en:
2022 was a year of facing challenges head-on.

At the beginning of 2022, the global economic environment was bleak. The Omicron variant of the coronavirus wreaked havoc, continuing to pressure global economic growth while inflationary pressures kept rising. Subsequently, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine further intensified inflationary pressures, prompting major central banks to adopt preemptive monetary tightening policies, amplifying volatility in global financial markets and increasing the risk of economic slowdown. Locally, the fifth wave of the pandemic hit Hong Kong, with a rapid surge in infection cases further damaging the economy. Meanwhile, negative media coverage surrounding quarantine measures and restrictions deepened misunderstandings about Hong Kong abroad, threatening its reputation as an international financial center. For the full year, Hong Kong's real local gross domestic product contracted by 3.5%.

Despite facing numerous challenges, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to strive to safeguard Hong Kong's monetary and financial stability, advancing multiple proactive measures across key strategic areas to further consolidate Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. Following three years of travel restrictions, we have successfully demonstrated to the international community that Hong Kong has fully resumed normal operations, allowing tourists to once again visit in person and experience the city firsthand. Last November, the HKMA hosted the "International Financial Leaders Investment Summit," drawing financial leaders from around the world to attend in person. The enthusiastic response from the international community has served as the most compelling evidence of Hong Kong's full recovery.

Looking ahead, the external environment remains fraught with unprecedented uncertainties. Nevertheless, the resumption of mainland economic activity will reinvigorate Hong Kong and the broader region. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will continue to steadfastly fulfill its mandate of maintaining the stability of Hong Kong's currency and banking system, while actively seeking more opportunities to support Hong Kong's development and enhance its competitiveness as an international financial center. We will also continue to contribute to global climate resilience and sustainable development. In addition to the 2022 Annual Report, we will issue a separate 2022 Sustainability Report this year to provide a more detailed overview of the HKMA's initiatives in strengthening Hong Kong's position as a green and sustainable finance hub, as well as the efforts made by the HKMA as a responsible investor and sustainable institution.

# Monetary and Financial System: As Firm as Ever

The Linked Exchange Rate System (LERS), implemented in 1983, has withstood multiple economic cycles and successfully resisted various external shocks. In 2022, the system's resilience was once again demonstrated. Amid the Federal Reserve's significant tightening of monetary policy, the weak-side exchange rate guarantee was triggered 41 times between May and November 2022. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) purchased a total of HKD 242.1 billion from the market in an orderly and transparent manner according to the established mechanism. During this period, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate and money market continued to operate smoothly, reflecting the robustness and effectiveness of the Linked Exchange Rate System.

The confidence in the linked exchange rate system stems from its solid foundation built over many years. As reiterated by the International Monetary Fund in its 2022 External Sector Report, the credibility of the linked exchange rate system is based on multiple factors, including operation rules with high transparency, ample foreign exchange reserves, a prudent fiscal system, sound financial regulation, and a flexible economic structure.

We firmly believe that, in addition to robust mechanisms, the dedication to communicating with the public and market to deepen their understanding of the linked exchange rate system, conducting effective market surveillance, and preparing contingency plans for different scenarios all contribute to strengthening confidence in the system. Our social media campaign launched to explain the operational mechanisms of the linked exchange rate system has helped effectively maintain market confidence, even during multiple triggers of the weak-side exchange guarantee this year. Internally, the HKMA has also effectively utilized data analytics technology to enhance market surveillance, enabling us to timely respond to the latest market developments.

Throughout the year, despite macro-level challenges and rising credit risks, Hong Kong's banking system remained resilient, with ample capital and liquidity. At the end of 2022, the consolidated capital adequacy ratio of local banks reached 20.1%, significantly higher than the international minimum requirement of 8%. In the fourth quarter of 2022, the liquidity coverage ratio of major banks slightly increased to 162.3%, also far exceeding the statutory minimum requirement of 100%. Given the challenges in the credit environment, the asset quality of the banking system slightly deteriorated, with the specific classification loan ratio rising to 1.38% by the end of 2022. However, this level remains robust and is lower than the long-term average of 1.8% since 2000.

# Banking System: Effective Regulation Ensures Operational Stability

The pandemic, which has lasted for three years, has intensified challenges from various fronts, such as escalating geopolitical tensions and major central banks tightening monetary policies. However, thanks to sound risk management practices and an effective regulatory framework developed over the years, Hong Kong's banking system has maintained robustness and continues to play a vital role in supporting the economy.

One of the main regulatory challenges faced over the past year has been ensuring that banks continue to provide necessary support to customers while maintaining robust credit risk management, amid ongoing economic uncertainties following the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic. The extension of the "pre-approved interest-only" program has been further prolonged, with the addition of a voluntary partial principal repayment option, allowing borrowers to choose to start repaying part of the principal, thereby helping customers prepare for resuming normal repayment schedules.

In response to increased market volatility caused by major economies significantly tightening monetary policies, another key regulatory initiative of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) in 2022 was to strengthen the monitoring of banks' market and liquidity risk exposure. We thoroughly assessed the potential impacts of the simultaneous tightening of monetary policies by various economies on banks, and introduced new scenarios into stress tests to evaluate banks' resilience to prolonged liquidity stress.

At the same time, we continue to take forward-looking measures to promote effective risk management across multiple areas. In terms of operational resilience and cyber defense capabilities, we provide guidance to help banks develop comprehensive and holistic operational frameworks to achieve resilient operations, and offer detailed regulatory guidance on specific operational areas, such as providing guidance on the use of cloud computing in response to the widespread adoption of cloud technology. Additionally, in response to the accelerated development of digitalization, we have also strengthened efforts to combat phishing scams and advanced work on consumer and investor protection.

In addition to maintaining the stability of the banking system, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is also committed to promoting financial inclusion and enhancing the convenience of banking services. Banks have responded positively to the HKMA's call for providing basic banking services, with some establishing new branches and self-service banking facilities in large public housing estates in new development areas. Affected by pandemic-related travel restrictions, many Hong Kong residents were unable to use their mainland bank accounts. Recognizing this, the HKMA closely collaborated with relevant parties to help restart approximately 500,000 mainland bank accounts, allowing affected account holders to do so without needing to personally visit mainland China.

Another strategically important area for the sustained development of the banking industry is enhancing professional capabilities. The demand for specialized talent remains substantial as the industry expands. Building on its talent development strategy — "Connecting Talent with the Future" — the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has introduced multiple initiatives over the past year to help the banking sector attract, nurture, and retain talent. These measures focus on enhancing and retraining the skills of existing professionals, as well as cultivating the younger generation to build a sustainable talent pool.

#International Financial Center: Hong Kong Returns to the International Stage!

The pandemic-related travel restrictions that had been in place for a long time were gradually lifted in 2022, and we made multifaceted efforts to bring Hong Kong back onto the global stage. The "International Financial Leaders Investment Summit" held in November attracted over 200 international and regional representatives from global financial institutions, drawing attention and enthusiastic responses from around the world. Despite the summit's dates coinciding with the first No. 8 typhoon signal issued in November in 50 years, the summit was still highly successful, sending a strong message to the world that Hong Kong has fully resumed normal operations and is demonstrating unprecedented vitality and energy. We are pleased to see the positive ripple effect generated by the summit, with many global financial institutions and international organizations currently or planning to hold various events in Hong Kong.

In addition to attracting visitors from around the world to return to Hong Kong, my colleagues and I at the Hong Kong Monetary Authority have realized the importance of face-to-face communication and connections. Therefore, we have made every effort to personally represent Hong Kong at major international conferences, actively participate in global policy discussions, and leverage overseas visits to meet with the executive management of global financial institutions, deepening their understanding of Hong Kong's robust financial system and the various opportunities Hong Kong offers under the "one country, two systems" framework.

To ensure Hong Kong maintains its competitiveness as an international financial center, we continue to push the boundaries of the market in strategic areas such as fintech, opportunities in the mainland, and green and sustainable finance. We are also further enhancing Hong Kong's financial infrastructure to provide top-tier services and attract more enterprises to establish themselves in Hong Kong. For details on the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's work in green and sustainable finance, please refer to the "2022 Sustainability Report."

# FinTech

Following the announcement of the "FinTech 2025" strategy in June 2021, we made significant progress across all five areas in 2022.

We have achieved satisfactory outcomes in our efforts to comprehensively promote the digitalization of banking. According to the results of the fintech application assessment, the Hong Kong banking industry has widely adopted fintech across various business areas, with the range of technology categories used continuously expanding. Our gradual promotion and support of digitalization efforts since 2017 have received a positive response from banks and have continued to yield results, with the outcomes being encouraging. We will continue to closely collaborate with the industry, based on the assessment results, to further promote the application of fintech in specific banking business areas and to advance the development of individual technology categories.

This year, our work on central bank digital currency (CBDC) has entered an important new phase. The "Multilateral Central Bank Digital Currency Cross-Border Network" (mBridge) project has entered its pilot phase, becoming one of the first CBDC initiatives globally to enable real settlement for cross-border corporate transactions. In the retail sector, technical testing for cross-border use of digital RMB has entered its second phase, primarily testing the use of the "TransferFast" system to top up digital RMB wallets. Regarding digital Hong Kong dollars, we will adopt a three-track approach to prepare for the potential future issuance of digital Hong Kong dollars, and launch the second track pilot program, inviting industry stakeholders to deeply explore feasible application scenarios for digital Hong Kong dollars.

Data can fully unlock the potential of fintech. The "Commercial Data Exchange," launched in October last year, represents a significant step forward in enhancing Hong Kong's data infrastructure. As a shared data infrastructure based on data owner authorization, the "Commercial Data Exchange" enables financial institutions to access business data, making it easier for companies, particularly SMEs, to obtain financing. By the end of 2022, the "Commercial Data Exchange" had facilitated over 1,000 SME loans, totaling over HKD 1.9 billion.

Finally, while embracing financial innovation and its benefits, we also recognize the necessity to monitor and address potential risks arising from related developments. We are closely monitoring the evolution of the virtual asset sector and participating in international discussions on relevant regulatory matters. Taking into account the opinions gathered from public consultations and relevant international standards, we will adopt the principle of "same risk, same regulation" (1) to establish a regulatory framework for stablecoins and define the scope of their regulation. In the future, our regulatory focus will initially target stablecoins that claim to be pegged to the value of one or more fiat currencies, as such stablecoins may pose higher and more pressing potential risks to monetary and financial stability. 在加強香港金融平台的競爭力方面取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、企業財資中心，以及綠色和可持續金融等範疇。

# 2022 Summary

# Economic and Financial Environment

Hong Kong's economy significantly contracted in 2022, affected by multiple adverse factors including the fifth wave of the coronavirus pandemic, tightening financial conditions, and a challenging external environment. The labor market initially deteriorated but gradually improved afterward, while inflation remained moderate. Benefiting from the full resumption of travel between mainland China and Hong Kong, Hong Kong's economic growth is expected to recover from its low base in 2023.

The Hong Kong banking system remained robust in 2022, with capital and liquidity conditions remaining ample and asset quality continuing to be at a healthy level.

# Currency Stability

With the U.S. tightening its monetary policy, the Hong Kong dollar has weakened, leading to the weak-side exchange guarantee being triggered multiple times this year. However, the Hong Kong foreign exchange and monetary markets have continued to operate in an orderly and smooth manner, repeatedly demonstrating the robustness and effectiveness of the linked exchange rate system.

# Reserve Management

The investment environment in 2022 was exceptionally volatile, with prices across multiple asset classes declining simultaneously. The foreign exchange fund reported an overall investment return of -4.5%, which, compared to the performance of most diversified asset funds in the market, represented a relatively moderate loss.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is also continuing to promote responsible investment and asset diversification. Meanwhile, the Long-term Growth Portfolio has achieved an annualized internal rate of return of 12.6% since the commencement of investments in 2009.

# Banking System Stability

In response to expanding volatility in financial markets, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has strengthened its oversight of banks' credit and market risk management, and is working closely with banks to enhance their operational resilience and cybersecurity capabilities, in order to address the persistent increase in cyber threats and the accelerated digital transformation of the banking sector.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has further introduced consumer protection measures concerning "buy now, pay later" products and new property mortgage payment arrangements. Additionally, the HKMA has collaborated with other regulatory bodies to establish a virtual asset regulatory framework, issued guidelines on the distribution of investment products, and launched a new trust business regulatory regime. The "Credit Information Platform" under the "Multiple Credit Information Service Providers" model was also launched this year.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to collaborate with banks to enhance Hong Kong's anti-money laundering (AML) ecosystem, strengthen measures to combat scams, and further promote the application of data and technology through its "AML Compliance Tech Lab" series, while accelerating the HKMA's adoption of regulatory technology in its AML efforts.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has made good progress in implementing international regulatory standards related to capital adequacy and disclosure requirements locally. The Authority has also collaborated with the banking sector to build a sustainable talent pool and enhance employees' skills for future development.

To ensure Hong Kong has a credible resolution mechanism, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has established new resolution standards, conducted regional crisis simulation exercises, and established a new layer of loss-absorbing capacity resources in all locally systemically important banks, marking a significant milestone in the development of the resolution mechanism.

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

The International Financial Leaders Investment Summit achieved success, consolidating Hong Kong's status as an international financial center and generating a positive ripple effect.

The currency swap agreement between the People's Bank of China and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority was optimized during the year, further consolidating Hong Kong's position as a global offshore RMB business hub. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also collaborated with other regulators and stakeholders to prepare for the launch of "Swap Connect" and to introduce a dual-trading-platform market maker mechanism to support the trading of RMB-denominated stocks in Hong Kong. Additionally, it is committed to developing the Central Clearing and Settlement System for Debt Instruments into a major international central securities depository platform in Asia.

Made good progress in enhancing the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform, covering areas such as bond issuance, asset and wealth management, corporate treasury centers, as well as green and sustainable finance, among other areas.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to implement the "FinTech 2025" strategy, promoting the adoption of financial technology by the financial industry and enhancing Hong Kong's status as a FinTech hub. The fast payment system "FPS" (轉數快) has seen steady growth in usage with enhanced features.

# Institutional Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains effective communication with the public and the market through various channels, enhancing the public's understanding of its policies and operations.

Internally, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has carefully established a work team emphasizing adaptability and sustainable development, while maintaining strict fiscal discipline and enhancing information technology capabilities to respond to changes and ensure the effective implementation of various policies and measures.

按揭證券公司宣布與14間合作銀行簽訂基建貸款合作框架《諒解備忘錄》，就基建貸款上的合作定立主要準則。

# 2月14日

金融學院轄下負責研究工作的香港貨幣及金融研究中心發表新一份題為《人口轉變及長期資產市場：香港的機遇及發展》的應用金融研究報告（英文版）。

# 3月8日

國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）代表團就香港特別行政區2022年第四條磋商發表評估報告，再次肯定香港作為主要國際金融中心的地位，具備穩健強韌的金融體系、有效的宏觀經濟及審慎政策，以及健全的規管及監管框架，並認同香港金融業在疫情期間，依然持續擴張和發展。

基金組織亦讚揚香港在應對氣候變化方面取得重大進展，並認同政府努力不懈加強綠色和可持續金融生態圈。

# 3月30日

綠色和可持續金融跨機構督導小組公布對香港碳市場機遇的初步可行性評估。根據評估結果，督導小組公布支持香港發展成為區域碳交易中心的後續工作。

# 2022 Major Events Summary

# Currency Stability

# May 26

The Government made its first issuance of HK$500 million 20-year Hong Kong dollar government bonds under the "Institutional Bond Issuance Program" through a bidding process.

# July 4th

The People's Bank of China (PBOC) and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced the optimization of their currency swap agreement, converting it into a standing agreement format that no longer requires renewal. The agreement's scale has been expanded from 500 billion RMB/590 billion HKD to 800 billion RMB/940 billion HKD.

# July 13th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued an updated commitment statement to reaffirm its commitment to adhere to the updated version of the Global Foreign Exchange Market Code when acting as a market participant.

# July 22nd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has announced the optimization of RMB liquidity arrangements, including expanding the scale and simplifying operations.

# Banking System

# January 28th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) have issued a joint circular providing updated guidance for intermediaries engaged in virtual asset-related activities to protect clients.

# January 28th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has updated its regulatory guidance on money laundering and terrorist financing risks related to bank management, virtual assets, and virtual asset service providers.

# February 8th

HKMA announced the extension of the "Banking Industry Talent Launch Program" by six months.

# February 23

Hong Kong Mortgage Securities Limited (Mortgage Securities Company), which wholly owns Hong Kong Mortgage Insurance Limited (Mortgage Insurance Company), announced that the Mortgage Insurance Plan has been amended and expanded in its scope of application for completed residential properties.

# February 23

The "100% Guaranteed Personal Privilege Loan Program" has introduced optimized measures (effective April 19, 2023) and extended the application period until the end of April 2023.

# February 23

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), together with the Banking Sector SME Loan Coordination Mechanism, announced the extension of the Pre-Approved Interest-Only Repayment Plan for an additional six months until the end of October. The principal repayment period for trade financing loans will also be extended by 90 days. The plan simultaneously offers a one-year partial principal repayment option, allowing borrowers who are willing and able to gradually resume normal repayment.

The Small and Medium-sized Enterprises Financing Guarantee Scheme has also introduced enhanced measures (effective from April 1) and extended the application period until June 30, 2023.

# April 1st

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Insurance Authority (IA) have introduced measures to enhance customer protection regarding the use of premium financing to purchase life insurance policies.

# April 14

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has issued guidelines to Hong Kong banks regarding assisting Hong Kong residents in restarting their mainland bank accounts under quarantine restrictions implemented due to the pandemic.

# April 26

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has launched the "Compliance Technology Information Platform" to encourage the Hong Kong compliance technology ecosystem to enhance the sharing of experience and specialized knowledge in the application of compliance technology.

# April 28th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced a joint initiative with the banking sector to launch the "Banking Industry Graduate Training Program," aimed at expanding the talent pool in the sector's rapidly growing areas.

# May 5

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has recognized the "Mandatory Background Check Program" to be implemented by the Hong Kong Bankers Association (Banking Association) and the Deposit-taking Companies Association, aimed at addressing the "rolling bad apple" phenomenon in the Hong Kong banking sector.

# May 6th

The 100% Guaranteed Personal Privilege Loan Program has begun accepting applications from individual property owners affected by the deferred rent collection arrangement, until October 31st.

# May 25th

The HKMA published the report titled "Special Assessment of the Reward System for Frontline Departments in Retail Banking" (English version) to continue promoting a stable and sound culture in the banking industry.

# May 27

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has issued the Operational Guidelines for Trust Business Operations and a new section in the Regulatory Policy Manual to strengthen the regulation and supervision of trust businesses in Hong Kong.

# May 31st

Hong Kong Annuity Limited, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Mortgage Securities Company, announced enhancements and promotional incentives for the Hong Kong Annuity Plan. The enhancements include increasing the upper limits for the "special withdrawal amount for medical and dental expenses" and the "total individual premium amount."

# June 23

The HKMA has released the results of the fintech application assessment and the related action plan to further support the industry's adoption of fintech.

# July 1

The 2022 Banking (Capital) (Amendment) Rules, enacted to implement the Basel Committee's capital requirements for banks' equity investments in funds, have come into effect.

# July 6–8

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) participated in the design and conduct of a three-day regional crisis simulation exercise. The exercise involved a total of 10 central banks, regulatory and resolution authorities, as well as deposit insurance institutions across the Asia-Pacific region, aiming to strengthen cross-border cooperation.

# July 8th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority provides guidance to authorized institutions on the sale of protection-type investment-linked life insurance, offering protection to customers.

# July 8th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued guidelines to banks and licensed payment service providers based on the main insights and related impacts outlined in the government's 2022 Hong Kong Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Risk Assessment Report.

# July 20th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority welcomes the Hong Kong Bankers' Association's announcement of providing an additional payment arrangement for residential property transfer transactions. Mortgage banks began offering this new property transaction payment arrangement on November 7.

# July 21

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and Digital Harbour, with the assistance of Deloitte, co-organized the second "Anti-Money Laundering Compliance Tech Lab" (AMLab 2), primarily focusing on user-friendly technologies with lower implementation thresholds and easier deployment.

# September 2nd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has introduced a series of consumer protection measures regarding banks' "buy now, pay later" products to promote responsible lending.

# September 8

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced the launch of the one-stop online resource platform "Banking Navigation" and the second edition of the "Banking Bridging Course."

# September 16

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the Interbank SME Loan Coordination Mechanism, announced the extension of the pre-approved interest-only repayment plan for three months until the end of January 2023.

On the same day, Mortgage Insurance Company announced that the interest-only payment arrangement under the Small and Medium-sized Enterprises Financing Guarantee Scheme has also been extended, allowing borrowing enterprises to apply for a deferral of principal repayments for a maximum total of 36 months.

# September 26th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has finalized the implementation guidelines for the "Fintech Professionals Training Subsidy Pilot Program" and officially launched the initiative in the banking sector.

# September 27th

The SFC and HKMA released the results of their second annual joint investigation on the sale of non-exchange-traded investment products by licensed corporations and registered institutions. # September 27th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has introduced a "Compliance" unit under the "Banking Professional Qualifications Framework" to collaborate with the banking industry in developing a set of capability standards that are commonly adoptable by the industry and transparent, with the aim of enhancing the professional capabilities of compliance professionals.

# October 6th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the Hong Kong Bankers' Association, banks, and the stored value payment tool industry, supports the Hong Kong Police Force in launching the scam trap search tool "Anti-Scam Vision Detector" to strengthen the prevention, detection, and suppression of fraudulent activities in society and reduce public financial losses.

In addition to issuing practical guidelines and updating relevant "Frequently Asked Questions" (FAQs), the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has collaborated with banks and the e-money industry to enhance public awareness against scams through consumer education materials on their website and social media platforms. The HKMA has also published articles in "Hui Si" to explain these efforts.

# October 20th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, in conjunction with the "Banking Sector SME Loan Coordination Mechanism," announced the extension of the "pre-approved interest-only repayment" program for six months until the end of July 2023, and optimized certain principal repayment options to assist capable businesses in preparing to gradually resume normal repayments in the future.

Anzhen Insurance Company also announced that the application period for the interest-only, no principal repayment arrangement under the SME Financing Guarantee Scheme has been extended by six months until the end of June 2023, with the upper limit extended by six months, bringing the total maximum to 42 months.

# October 21st

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued two notices to update the requirements related to the sales and distribution of loss-making products and to provide guidance on suitability assessments.

# November 24th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), in collaboration with Digital Harbour and with the assistance of Deloitte, hosted the third "Anti-Money Laundering Compliance Tech Lab (AMLab 3)." Building on the achievements of previous AMLab series, AMLab 3 utilizes network analysis to address fraud risks and reduce losses caused by puppet account network scams.

# November 28th

With the strong support of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), the "Credit Information Platform" under the "multiple credit information service providers" model has commenced operations, aiming to enhance the service standards of Hong Kong's personal credit information service providers and reduce the operational risks stemming from the current market's reliance on a single commercial operator.

# December 7th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued a notice to banks regarding the upcoming 2022 Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (Amendment) Bill, which will take effect in June 2023, clarifying the latest amendments related to the banking sector.

# December 15th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) organized a seminar on combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism (AML) for banks and the electronic payment institutions sector. The seminar covered updates on regulatory requirements, AML regulatory technology (RegTech) and compliance technology, regulatory requirements regarding the source of wealth, feedback on suspicious transaction reports, and updates on combating the financing of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMDs).

# December 23

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), the Insurance Authority (IA), and the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) jointly issued a circular outlining the main results of their first collaborative inspection plan on the methods used by intermediaries in selling two tax-deductible products—qualified deferred annuity policies and MPF tax-deductible voluntary contributions—as well as the good practices observed during the inspection.

# December 31

All systemically important banks in Hong Kong have established a new layer of financial resources to absorb losses during resolution, marking a milestone for the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) in enhancing the feasibility of resolving such banks and the stability of the banking system.

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

# January 12

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has released a discussion paper on cryptocurrencies and stablecoins, outlining its conceptual framework for regulating cryptocurrencies, particularly stablecoins used for payment purposes, and inviting industry stakeholders and the public to provide feedback on the proposed regulatory framework.

# January 27th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Secretariat for International Financial Affairs under the Swiss Federal Department of Finance co-hosted the fifth Hong Kong-Switzerland Financial Cooperation Dialogue online.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has been reappointed as Co-Chairman of the Assessment and Compliance Subcommittee under the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) for a two-year term. The FATF is the global standard-setting organization for anti-money laundering.

Mortgage Securities Company announced the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding with 14 partner banks to establish key guidelines for cooperation in infrastructure loans.

# February 14

The Hong Kong Monetary and Financial Research Centre, responsible for research work under the School of Finance, has published a new applied financial research report (English version) titled "Demographic Changes and Long-Term Asset Markets: Opportunities and Development for Hong Kong."

# March 8

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) delegation issued an assessment report on the 2022 Fourth Article consultation for the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, reaffirming Hong Kong's status as a major international financial center. The report highlighted Hong Kong's robust and resilient financial system, effective macroeconomic and prudent policies, as well as a sound regulatory and supervisory framework. It also acknowledged that Hong Kong's financial sector continued to expand and develop during the pandemic.

The fund organization also praised Hong Kong's significant progress in addressing climate change and acknowledged the government's relentless efforts to strengthen the green and sustainable financial ecosystem.

The Inter-Agency Steering Group on Green and Sustainable Finance has released an initial feasibility assessment on opportunities for Hong Kong's carbon market. Based on the assessment results, the steering group announced follow-up actions to support Hong Kong's development into a regional carbon trading hub.

# April 12th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has issued a discussion paper titled "From a Policy and Design Perspective: The Digital Hong Kong Dollar," which outlines the key policy and design considerations involved in introducing a retail central bank digital currency (i.e., the Digital Hong Kong Dollar or e-HKD) in Hong Kong, and seeks public opinion.

# May 3rd

The Green Banking Alliance, initiated by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the International Finance Corporation (a member of the World Bank Group), co-hosted an online roundtable conference titled "Green and Sustainable Capital Markets Transformation" with Standard Chartered Bank.

# 2023年工作重點及前瞻

儘管香港經濟在2023 年初出現復甦跡象，但外圍環境仍然充滿挑戰及不確定性。近期美國和歐洲的銀行業受壓，個別美國本土銀行在2023 年3 月倒閉，對環球金融市場造成漣漪效應，而主要央行收緊貨幣政策，很有可能令2023 年全球經濟增長放緩甚或衰退。另一方面，地緣政治局勢緊張，以及去全球化的威脅持續，可能會繼續拖累全球貿易，並會令環球金融市場不時出現波動。儘管如此，香港金融體系憑藉多年來所建立穩健的抗震能力及充裕的緩衝，有足夠能力抵禦不利衝擊。

金管局非常重視保障貨幣及金融穩定。展望未來，面對不明朗的宏觀經濟環境，金管局會保持警惕，力求迅速辨識正浮現的風險，並靈活應對。與此同時，金管局會繼續把握機遇及創造政策空間，進一步提升香港作為主要國際金融中心的地位。面對充滿挑戰的投資環境，金管局在管理外匯基金時會繼續審慎投資，同時保持足夠靈活性，按需要採取防禦措施，並維持高流動性。

# 金融體系保持穩定健全

環球經濟前景仍受制於重大的不確定因素。金管局會密切注視最新發展，提高警覺，防範各種潛在風險，以維持金融體系穩定健全；這是關乎持續提供關鍵金融服務的先決條件，因此亦是維繫香港經濟正常運作的命脈。

# 對潛在風險保持警惕

在2023年，美國利率未來走勢的不確定性，以及在先進經濟體銀行體系出現的壓力，可能會對主要先進經濟體的增長前景帶來下行風險。此外，持續的地緣政治風險，可能會繼續拖累全球貿易，並會令環球金融市場不時出現波動。然而，香港金融體系憑藉過去多年所建立的抗震能力及緩衝，有足夠能力抵禦不利衝擊。金管局亦有能力、資源及決心維持香港貨幣及金融穩定。

金管局將繼續密切注視本地及外圍環境的風險與脆弱性，並會按需要採取適當措施維持香港的貨幣及金融體系穩定。金管局亦會研究對香港經濟有影響的事項，以及評估與這些事項相關的潛在風險。

# 保持銀行體系穩定

鑑於地緣政治緊張局勢升級，以及各主要央行大幅加息以遏抑通脹，預計2023年銀行業的經營環境仍然充滿挑戰。另一方面，科技發展迅速及數碼化對銀行業來說既有危又有機。面對瞬息萬變的金融環境，金管局致力透過持續的監管工作確保銀行具足夠能力抵禦衝擊。與此同時，金管局亦會參照國際標準及最佳做法，繼續加強及優化銀行監管架構與政策。

# 風險為本的監管重點

# 信用、流動性及市場風險

在2023年，金管局將繼續密切注視認可機構的資產質素，並聚焦於認可機構的貸款分類及撥備做法，以及對財務狀況較差的借款人的管理。金管局亦會加強其監察系統，並採取積極措施確保銀行體系的整體信用風險水平維持可控。

另一方面，金管局會繼續留意企業的營運環境，並與銀行業及商界保持緊密溝通，以就最終退出「預先批核還息不還本」計劃作好準備，並同時確保暫時面對困難的客戶仍然得到適切的信貸支援。

此外，面對不明朗的宏觀經濟環境，金管局於2023年亦會加強監管認可機構的流動性及市場風險管理。

# 業務操作及科技風險

隨着銀行在業務營運中更廣泛應用科技，金管局會致力提升銀行業的運作穩健性及網絡防衛能力。繼5月發出《監管政策手冊》新單元「運作穩健性」後，金管局會與業界保持緊密聯繫，審視認可機構在制定運作穩健性框架方面的進度。同時，金管局將透過跟進認可機構在「網絡防衛評估框架2.0」評估下發現的問題以及檢視認可機構實施穩固三重數據備份的進展，提高銀行業的網絡防衛能力。

隨着數碼化的步伐加快，金管局的其他監管重點包括加強對銀行的第三方服務供應商風險管理的監管，以及提升銀行業的數據管治能力。

# 打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集

在2023年，金管局的工作重點包括更新監管資訊、加強打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（反洗錢）生態系統各持份者的合作以應對洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（洗錢）風險，以及進一步推動反洗錢監管科技與合規科技的發展。金管局的《打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集指引》亦會作出修訂，並會就「政治人物」採取與風險相稱的措施發出具體指引，從而促進業界以有效及風險為本的方法落實法例的主要修訂。與此同時，金管局會擴大現有公私營夥伴合作的涵蓋範圍以加強訊息共享，以及支持推出銀行之間的訊息共享平台，藉以加快偵測可疑戶口及防範戶口被濫用，並加強對騙案受害人的保障和協助受害人追討損失。金管局亦會透過「反洗錢合規科技實驗室」及其他反洗錢合規科技項目，進一步集中推動採用合規科技（包括數據分析），並致力發展宏觀分析能力，以配合其數據為本的反洗錢監管工作。透過實施上述各項措施，金管局將能更迅速針對傀儡戶口網絡等系統性洗錢風險採取相應措施，以及靈活應對不斷轉變的威脅。

# 財富管理業務

金管局在2023年會加強有關認可機構在財富管理以及銷售證券、強制性公積金（強積金）與其他投資及保險產品方面的操守的現場審查及非現場監察。2023年的重點將會是「跨境理財通」計劃、數碼分銷及諮詢平台、虛擬資產、環境、社會及管治(ESG)投資產品及長期保險產品。金管局在有關過程中會參考市場最新發展及國際標準的修訂。

金管局亦會與其他監管機構及銀行界緊密聯繫，並按需要就銷售投資、保險及強積金產品的監管標準向認可機構提供指引，其中亦會包括有關提供虛擬資產相關投資服務的指引。就此而言，為促進虛擬資產行業可持續及負責任地發展，金管局會積極參與相關國際組織，並與政府及其他金融監管機構合作，制定全面的虛擬資產監管架構。

隨着「跨境理財通」順利推出，金管局會與業界及相關監管機構聯繫，以優化該計劃。此外，金管局亦會與證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會）及業界合作，精簡投資產品銷售程序（包括適用於資深投資者的銷售程序），以及開始根據相關《監管政策手冊》新單元及新營運守則監管認可機構的信託業務。

# 監察金融市場基建

金管局的目標是按照《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）、《金融市場基建的原則》（《基建原則》），以及支付及金融基建委員會發出的各項指引促進其所監察的金融市場基建的安全及效率，按需要參照最新的國際標準評估各項基建。金管局會參與支付及金融基建委員會與國際證監會組織對實施《基建原則》的監察及評估計劃，亦會參與國際標準制定組織的工作，並參照國際慣例或因應市場及科技發展加強本身的監察規定。同時，如有需要，金管局會與有關當局合作，進一步加強合作監察安排。

# 制定政策

金管局會因應國際標準及最佳做法，繼續加強及優化銀行監管架構與政策。

# 在香港實施巴塞爾標準

# 資本標準

金管局會透過實施巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）近年發布的標準，進一步優化資本框架，當中包括：
- 2017年12月《巴塞爾協定三：危機後改革的最終方案》、2019年1月（2019年2月修訂）《市場風險最低資本規定》，以及2020年7月《信用估值調整風險架構具針對性的修訂》所載的經修訂資本標準 — 上述經修訂資本標準統稱《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案，載明信用風險、市場風險、信用估值調整風險及業務操作風險的新監管處理方法，並引入出項下限規定，以及優化槓桿比率框架。經過2022年的多輪業界諮詢後，金管局計劃在2023年就《銀行業（資本）規則》（《資本規則》）的建議修訂進行法定諮詢，以實施上述各項規定及正值中性逆周期緩衝資本。有關修訂預計於同年內提交立法會進行先訂立後審議程序，並不早於2024年1月1日生效，作為最低要求。
- 2022年12月《加密資產風險承擔的審慎處理方法》金管局計劃按照巴塞爾委員會的時間表，在2025年1月1日於本地實施有關標準，並打算於2023年就相關建議諮詢業界。

# 風險承擔限度

金管局於2023年3月就《銀行業（風險承擔限度）規則》的建議修訂諮詢業界。有關建議修訂主要是因應金管局實施上文提及的《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案下的經修訂資本標準而提出。諮詢文件亦包括就《資本規則》下有關官方實體集中風險的處理方法所作出的其他相應修訂。經修訂規則的目標實施日期將與落實《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案的經修訂《資本規則》中的信用風險部分的實施日期一致（即不早於2024年1月1日）。

# 流動性標準

金管局擬於2023年諮詢業界有關透過《2023年銀行業（流動性）（修訂）規則》（《2023年流動性修訂規則》）對《銀行業（流動性）規則》作出的建議修訂。相關修訂是因應同時期的《資本規則》建議修訂而作出，所以《2023年流動性修訂規則》的目標實施日期將與落實《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案的經修訂《資本規則》中的信用風險部分的實施日期一致（即不早於2024年1月1日）。

# 披露標準

《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案中與經修訂資本標準相關的新的及經修訂的披露規定，主要載於巴塞爾委員會分別於2018年12月及2021年11月發出的《第三支柱1 披露規定 — 更新框架》及《修訂市場風險披露規定》。巴塞爾委員會亦於2019年6月發出《修訂槓桿比率披露規定》，藉修訂槓桿比率的披露規定處理對潛在「粉飾櫥窗」（指銀行在報告日期前後減少某些交易的交易量，從而人為地提高報告及公開披露的槓桿比率）的關注。為在香港實施上述新的及經修訂的披露規定，金管局亦正擬備《銀行業（披露）規則》（《披露規則》）的相應修訂，以及經修訂後的標準披露模版及表格，並在過程中徵詢業界意見。預計《披露規則》的修訂將於2023年內連同《資本規則》的修訂一併提交立法會進行先訂立後審議程序。

# 2023 Work Priorities and Future Outlook

Although the Hong Kong economy showed signs of recovery in early 2023, the external environment remains fraught with challenges and uncertainties. Recently, the banking sectors in the United States and Europe have faced pressure, with individual U.S. banks closing in March 2023, creating ripple effects across global financial markets. The tightening of monetary policies by major central banks could likely lead to a slowdown or even a recession in global economic growth in 2023. Meanwhile, ongoing geopolitical tensions and the persistent threat of deglobalization may continue to hinder global trade and cause periodic volatility in global financial markets. Nevertheless, Hong Kong's financial system, supported by its robust resilience and ample buffers built up over the years, is well-equipped to withstand adverse shocks.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) places great emphasis on safeguarding currency and financial stability. Looking ahead, in the face of an uncertain macroeconomic environment, the HKMA will remain vigilant, striving to swiftly identify emerging risks and respond flexibly. At the same time, the HKMA will continue to seize opportunities and create policy space to further enhance Hong Kong's status as a major international financial center. In a challenging investment environment, the HKMA will continue to prudently manage the Exchange Fund's investments while maintaining sufficient flexibility to take defensive measures as needed and ensuring high liquidity.

# The financial system remains stable and sound.

The global economic outlook remains constrained by significant uncertainties. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will closely monitor the latest developments, heighten vigilance, and guard against various potential risks to maintain a stable and sound financial system. This is a prerequisite for the continued provision of critical financial services and, therefore, the lifeline for maintaining the normal operation of Hong Kong's economy.

# Stay Vigilant to Potential Risks

In 2023, uncertainty surrounding the future path of U.S. interest rates, along with pressures emerging in the banking systems of advanced economies, could pose downside risks to the growth prospects of major advanced economies. Furthermore, ongoing geopolitical risks may continue to weigh on global trade and could lead to periodic volatility in global financial markets. However, Hong Kong's financial system, with its resilience and buffers built up over the years, has sufficient capacity to withstand adverse shocks. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) also has the capability, resources, and determination to maintain Hong Kong's monetary and financial stability.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to closely monitor risks and vulnerabilities in both local and external environments, and will take appropriate measures as needed to maintain the stability of Hong Kong's monetary and financial systems. The Authority will also study matters that affect Hong Kong's economy and assess the potential risks associated with these matters.

# Maintain the stability of the banking system

In light of the escalating geopolitical tensions and major central banks significantly raising interest rates to curb inflation, the operating environment for the banking sector in 2023 is still expected to be challenging. On the other hand, rapid technological development and digitalization present both threats and opportunities for the banking industry. Facing an ever-changing financial landscape, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to ensuring banks have sufficient capacity to withstand shocks through continuous regulatory efforts. At the same time, the HKMA will continue to strengthen and optimize its banking regulatory framework and policies by referring to international standards and best practices.

# Risk-Based Regulatory Priorities

# Credit, Liquidity, and Market Risk

In 2023, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to closely monitor the asset quality of authorized institutions, focusing on their loan classification and provisioning practices, as well as the management of borrowers with weaker financial conditions. The Authority will also enhance its supervisory system and take proactive measures to ensure the overall credit risk level in the banking system remains manageable.

On the other hand, the HKMA will continue to monitor the operating environment of businesses and maintain close communication with the banking sector and the business community to prepare for the eventual exit from the "pre-approved interest-only" loan program, while simultaneously ensuring that customers facing temporary difficulties continue to receive adequate credit support.

In addition, in response to the uncertain macroeconomic environment, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will strengthen its oversight of authorized institutions' liquidity and market risk management in 2023.

# Business Operations and Technology Risks

As banks increasingly adopt technology in their business operations, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to enhancing the operational resilience and cybersecurity capabilities of the banking sector. Following the issuance of a new section titled "Operational Resilience" in the "Regulatory Policy Manual" in May, the HKMA will maintain close communication with the industry to review the progress of authorized institutions in establishing operational resilience frameworks. At the same time, the HKMA will enhance the banking sector's cybersecurity capabilities by following up on issues identified in the "Cybersecurity Assessment Framework 2.0" and examining the progress of authorized institutions in implementing robust triple data backup measures.

As the pace of digitization accelerates, the HKMA's other regulatory priorities include strengthening the regulation of risk management related to banks' third-party service providers, as well as enhancing the data governance capabilities of the banking industry.

#CombatMoneyLaunderingAndTerroristFinancing

In 2023, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will focus on updating regulatory information, enhancing collaboration among stakeholders in the anti-money laundering (AML) and counter-terrorism financing ecosystem to address money laundering and terrorism financing risks, and further promoting the development of AML regulatory technology and compliance technology. The HKMA's "Guidelines on Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing" will also be revised, providing specific guidance on implementing proportionate measures based on risk for "politically exposed persons," thereby facilitating the industry's effective and risk-based implementation of key legislative amendments. At the same time, the HKMA will expand the scope of existing public-private partnerships to strengthen information sharing and support the launch of an inter-bank information sharing platform to accelerate the detection of suspicious accounts, prevent account abuse, and enhance protection for victims of scams and assistance in recovering losses. The HKMA will also further focus on promoting the adoption of compliance technology, including data analytics, through the "Anti-Money Laundering Compliance Technology Laboratory" and other AML compliance technology initiatives, and strive to develop macro-level analytical capabilities to support its data-driven AML regulatory work. Through the implementation of these measures, the HKMA will be able to respond more swiftly to systemic money laundering risks such as puppet account networks and flexibly address evolving threats.

# Wealth Management Services

In 2023, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will enhance on-site inspections and off-site monitoring of authorized institutions regarding their conduct in wealth management, as well as the sale of securities, Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF), and other investment and insurance products. The key focus areas in 2023 will include the "Cross-Border Wealth Management Connect" program, digital distribution and advisory platforms, virtual assets, environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investment products, and long-term insurance products. Throughout the process, the HKMA will take into account the latest market developments and revisions to international standards.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will also maintain close communication with other regulatory bodies and the banking sector, and provide guidance as needed to authorized institutions on regulatory standards for the sale of investment, insurance, and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) products, which will also include guidance on providing investment services related to virtual assets. In this regard, to promote the sustainable and responsible development of the virtual asset industry, the HKMA will actively participate in relevant international organizations and collaborate with the government and other financial regulators to establish a comprehensive regulatory framework for virtual assets.

With the smooth launch of the Cross-Border Wealth Management Connect, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will coordinate with the industry and relevant regulatory bodies to optimize the program. In addition, the HKMA will collaborate with the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) and the industry to streamline the sales procedures for investment products (including procedures applicable to sophisticated investors), and will begin regulating the trust businesses of authorized institutions in accordance with the new unit and new operational guidelines in the relevant Regulatory Policy Manual.

# Supervise Financial Market Infrastructure

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) aims to promote the safety and efficiency of financial market infrastructures under its supervision in accordance with the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (Payment Ordinance), the Principles for Financial Market Infrastructures (Infrastructure Principles), and the guidelines issued by the Payment and Financial Market Infrastructure Committee. The HKMA will assess various infrastructures in line with the latest international standards as needed, participate in the oversight and evaluation programs conducted by the Payment and Financial Market Infrastructure Committee and the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) regarding the implementation of the Infrastructure Principles, engage in the work of international standard-setting organizations, and enhance its own oversight requirements by referencing international practices or adapting to market and technological developments. Additionally, the HKMA will cooperate with relevant authorities as necessary to further strengthen collaborative oversight arrangements.

# Formulate Policies

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to strengthen and optimize the banking regulatory framework and policies in accordance with international standards and best practices.

# Implementing Basel Standards in Hong Kong

#CapitalStandard

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will further optimize its capital framework by implementing the standards issued recently by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, including:  
- The revised capital standards set out in the Basel III: Finalising Post-Crisis Reforms (December 2017), the Minimum Capital Requirements for Market Risk (January 2019, revised in February 2019), and the Targeted amendments to the Risk Framework for Credit Valuation Adjustment Risk (July 2020). These revised capital standards, collectively referred to as the Basel III Final Reforms, outline new regulatory approaches for credit risk, market risk, credit valuation adjustment risk, and operational risk, and introduce floor requirements as well as an optimized leverage ratio framework. Following multiple rounds of industry consultations in 2022, the HKMA plans to conduct a statutory consultation on the proposed amendments to the Banking (Capital) Rules (Capital Rules) in 2023 to implement the aforementioned requirements and the neutral countercyclical capital buffer. The proposed amendments are expected to be submitted to the Legislative Council for pre-legislative scrutiny in the same year and will not take effect earlier than January 1, 2024, as the minimum requirement.  
- The Prudential Treatment of Risks from Crypto-Assets (December 2022). The HKMA plans to implement these standards locally by January 1, 2025, in line with the Basel Committee's timetable, and intends to consult the industry on the related proposals in 2023.

# Risk Tolerance

In March 2023, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) consulted the industry on proposed amendments to the Banking (Risk Limitation) Rules. These proposed amendments were primarily introduced in response to the HKMA's implementation of revised capital standards under the Basel III final reform package. The consultation paper also included other corresponding revisions regarding the handling of concentrated risks from official entities under the Capital Rules. The target implementation date for the revised rules will align with the implementation date of the credit risk component under the revised Capital Rules related to the Basel III final reform package (i.e., no earlier than January 1, 2024).

# Liquidity Standards

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) plans to consult the industry in 2023 on proposed amendments to the Banking (Liquidity) Rules through the 2023 Banking (Liquidity) (Amendment) Rules (the "2023 Liquidity Amendment Rules"). These amendments are made in response to the proposed amendments to the Capital Rules during the same period. Therefore, the target implementation date for the 2023 Liquidity Amendment Rules will align with the implementation date of the credit risk component in the revised Capital Rules under the Basel III Final Reform Package (i.e., no earlier than January 1, 2024).

# Disclosure Standards

The new and revised disclosure requirements related to the revised capital standards under the final reform package of Basel III are primarily outlined in two documents issued by the Basel Committee: "Third Pillar 1 Disclosure Requirements – Updated Framework," released in December 2018, and "Revised Market Risk Disclosure Requirements," issued in November 2021. In addition, the Basel Committee issued "Revised Leverage Ratio Disclosure Requirements" in June 2019, aiming to address concerns regarding potential "window dressing" (i.e., banks reducing certain transaction volumes before or after the reporting date to artificially inflate reported and publicly disclosed leverage ratios). To implement these new and revised disclosure requirements in Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is also preparing corresponding amendments to the "Banking (Disclosure) Rules" (the "Disclosure Rules"), as well as revised standard disclosure templates and forms, while seeking industry feedback throughout the process. It is expected that the amendments to the Disclosure Rules will be submitted to the Legislative Council for pre-legislative scrutiny together with the amendments to the Capital Rules in 2023.

# 機構管治

金管局作為香港的中央銀行機構，深明良好的管治對維持及維護公眾對金管局履行其法定職責的信任及信心的重要性，因此一直致力秉持高水平的機構管治。

為實踐良好機構管治的承諾，金管局：
- 建立了一套清晰且具備高問責性的機構管治架構；
- 實施完善穩健的監控措施以管理風險，並確保所有職級員工的行為及其日常運作均符合指定標準；及
- 奉行具透明度及保持開放的政策，與各持份者保持緊密聯繫。

# 金管局與香港特別行政區政府

金管局是香港特別行政區政府（特區政府）架構的一部分，但可以按與公務員不同的聘用條款聘請員工，以吸引具適當經驗與專門知識的人才。金管局總裁及其員工均為公職人員。金管局的日常運作，在金融管理專員所獲賦予或轉授的法定權力範圍內高度自主。

財政司司長負責釐定香港的貨幣政策目標及貨幣體制：財政司司長於2003年6月25日致金融管理專員的函件中，訂明應透過貨幣發行局制度維持貨幣穩定，將港元匯率保持在約7.80港元兌1美元的水平。金融管理專員須自行負責達成貨幣政策目標，包括決定有關的策略、工具及執行方式，並負責維持香港貨幣制度的穩定與健全。

財政司司長在財經事務及庫務局局長的協助下，負責維持香港金融體系穩定與健全，以及保持香港的國際金融中心地位的政策。為推行這些政策，金融管理專員的職責包括：
- 促進銀行體系的整體穩定與有效運作；
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，發展債務市場；
- 處理與法定紙幣及硬幣的發行及流通有關的事宜；
- 透過發展支付、結算及交收系統，以及在適當情況下負責操作有關系統，促進金融基建的安全與效率；及
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，促進對香港貨幣及金融體系的信心，並推行適當的發展市場措施，以協助加強香港金融服務的國際競爭力。

外匯基金由財政司司長掌有控制權。金融管理專員須根據財政司司長轉授的權力，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 問責性與透明度

就日常運作及推行政府政策目標所採用的方法，金管局一直保持高度自主，並同時輔以高問責性及透明度。

金管局致力促進貨幣與銀行體系穩定，有效管理官方儲備，發展與監察穩健及多元化的金融基建，從而鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，推動香港經濟發展。

金管局要有效履行職責，便必須取得社會人士的信任。因此，金管局以嚴謹的態度，履行向公眾解釋其政策及工作的責任，並盡力處理備受社會關注而涉及金管局職責範圍的事項。尤其，金管局透過傳統及社交媒體適時澄清有關金管局政策的失實資訊及謠言。

金融管理專員由財政司司長委任，因此金管局透過財政司司長向公眾負責；而由於金管局的職權由立法會通過的法律制訂，因此金管局亦透過立法會向公眾負責。金管局亦明白本身肩負更廣泛的責任，就是促進公眾對金管局角色及目標的認識，並密切留意社會人士所關注的事項。金管局在執行日常工作及與社會保持廣泛聯繫時，堅守盡力提高透明度及保持開放的政策。這項政策有兩大目標：
- 在顧及市場敏感性、商業秘密及機密資料披露的法定限制下，盡量使金融界及公眾充分了解金管局的工作；及
- 確保金管局掌握社會脈搏，並對公眾意見作出適當回應。

金管局在透明度方面致力達致國際最高標準，與傳媒保持廣泛聯繫之餘，亦出版各種中英文期刊及專題刊物。金管局的雙語網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)除有專門環節列載經濟研究、統計資料、監管資源、消費者資訊及其他課題外，還載有大量金管局出版的刊物、新聞稿、演辭及簡報會資料文件。此外，金管局又利用社交媒體平台，以能在數碼時代中更有效與公眾溝通。金管局辦事處設有資訊中心，分為圖書館及展覽館兩部分，每星期開放6日予公眾參觀及使用。有關金管局與公眾溝通及聯繫的工作，詳見「機構職能」一章（第157至162頁）。

金管局公布外匯基金及貨幣發行局帳目資料的次數，一直逐步增加，內容亦越趨詳細。金管局於1999年開始參與國際貨幣基金組織的中央銀行「數據公布特殊標準」計劃。金管局亦公布外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下貨幣發行委員會的會議紀錄，以及貨幣發行局制度運作報告。自1996年起，金管局網站載有銀行業監管政策及指引。

金管局與立法會的關係對提高問責性及透明度非常重要。金管局總裁承諾每年3次向立法會財經事務委員會簡報金管局各項工作及政策，並回答有關查詢。此外，金管局代表不時出席立法會事務委員會及小組委員會會議，闡釋及商討特別事項，以及協助議員審閱條例草案。

# 監控措施

金管局採用穩健有效的內部及外部監控機制，確保秉持高水平的員工操守、審慎的風險管理，以及適當的制衡。內部及外部審計職能就監控機制是否足夠及具成效提供獨立評估。

# 行為守則

《行為守則》就員工的道德與法律責任提供指引，確保所有職級員工的行為均符合指定標準。

# 內部監控

# 運作監控

作為風險管理的第一度防線，所有部門及分處均有責任評估其工作流程的風險，並制定適當的監控措施，確保金管局日常運作穩妥。

# 機構風險管理

風險管理亦在機構層面進行。由金管局總裁擔任主席的風險委員會，是機構風險管理架構的基石之一。

風險委員會審視和商討各部門所識別的潛在及新生風險，以及相關監控措施和緩解策略是否充足，並由該會定出適當的跟進行動。

# 內部審計

金管局內部審核處獨立評估不同部門的管治程序、風險管理及監控措施是否足夠及具成效，並提出改善建議。

# 外部審計

根據《外匯基金條例》第7條，外匯基金的財務報表由香港特區政府審計署審核。審計署並無就此項服務收取費用。經審核的外匯基金財務報表刊載於金管局《年報》。

# Institutional Governance

As Hong Kong's central banking institution, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority fully understands the importance of good governance in maintaining and upholding public trust and confidence in the Authority's statutory duties. Therefore, it has consistently strived to uphold high standards of institutional governance.

To demonstrate its commitment to good institutional governance, the HKMA:  
- Established a clear and highly accountable institutional governance framework;  
- Implemented comprehensive and robust monitoring measures to manage risks and ensure that the behavior and daily operations of all staff comply with specified standards; and  
- Upheld transparent and open policies, maintaining close communication with all stakeholders.

# HKMA and the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is part of the structure of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government (HKSARG), but it can appoint staff under terms of employment different from those of civil servants in order to attract individuals with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. The HKMA's Chief Executive and its staff are considered public officials. The HKMA's day-to-day operations are highly autonomous within the legal powers granted to or delegated by the Financial Secretary.

The Financial Secretary is responsible for determining Hong Kong's monetary policy objectives and currency system. In a letter dated June 25, 2003, addressed to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Financial Secretary specified that currency stability should be maintained through the Exchange Fund system, keeping the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate at approximately 7.80 Hong Kong dollars to 1 US dollar. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is autonomously responsible for achieving monetary policy objectives, including deciding on relevant strategies, tools, and methods of implementation, and for maintaining the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's currency system.

The Financial Secretary, with the assistance of the Secretary for Financial Services and the Treasury, is responsible for policies aimed at maintaining the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's financial system and preserving Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. To implement these policies, the Financial Controller's responsibilities include:  
- Promoting the overall stability and efficient operation of the banking system;  
- Collaborating with other relevant institutions and organizations to develop debt markets;  
- Handling matters related to the issuance and circulation of legal tender notes and coins;  
- Promoting the safety and efficiency of financial infrastructure through the development of payment, settlement, and clearing systems, and where appropriate, operating such systems; and  
- Collaborating with other relevant institutions and organizations to enhance confidence in Hong Kong's currency and financial system, and implementing appropriate market development measures to strengthen the international competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial services.

The Foreign Exchange Fund is under the control of the Financial Secretary. The Financial Controller must act under the authority delegated by the Financial Secretary and be responsible to the Financial Secretary regarding the management and investment of the Foreign Exchange Fund.

# Accountability and Transparency

In terms of the methods used in daily operations and the implementation of government policy objectives, the HKMA has consistently maintained a high degree of autonomy, coupled with strong accountability and transparency.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to promoting the stability of the monetary and banking system, effectively managing official reserves, developing and overseeing a robust and diversified financial infrastructure, thereby consolidating Hong Kong's status as an international financial center and driving Hong Kong's economic development.

To effectively perform its duties, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) must gain the trust of the public. Therefore, the HKMA adopts a rigorous approach in explaining its policies and operations to the public, and makes every effort to address issues of public concern that fall within its mandate. In particular, the HKMA timely clarifies false information and rumors regarding its policies through both traditional and social media channels.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is appointed by the Financial Secretary and is therefore accountable to the public through the Financial Secretary. Additionally, as the HKMA's authority is established by laws enacted by the Legislative Council, it is also accountable to the public through the Legislative Council. The HKMA also recognizes its broader responsibility to promote public understanding of its role and objectives, and to closely monitor matters of public concern. In carrying out its daily operations and maintaining extensive engagement with society, the HKMA adheres to a policy of striving to enhance transparency and maintain openness. This policy has two main objectives:  
- To the greatest extent possible, ensuring that the financial sector and the public are fully informed about the HKMA's work, while taking into account legal restrictions on the disclosure of sensitive information, commercial secrets, and confidential data; and  
- To ensure that the HKMA remains attuned to public sentiment and responds appropriately to public opinion.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to achieving international best standards in transparency. In addition to maintaining extensive contact with the media, the HKMA publishes a variety of bilingual journals and special publications. The HKMA's bilingual website (www.hkma.gov.hk) features dedicated sections listing economic research, statistical data, regulatory resources, consumer information, and other topics, and also hosts a large volume of publications, press releases, speeches, and briefing materials issued by the HKMA. Furthermore, the HKMA utilizes social media platforms to communicate more effectively with the public in the digital age. The HKMA's office houses an information center, divided into a library and an exhibition hall, which is open to the public six days a week for visits and use. Details regarding the HKMA's work in communication and engagement with the public can be found in the chapter "Functions of the Institution" (pages 157 to 162).

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has progressively increased the frequency of disclosing information regarding the Exchange Fund and the Currency Board, with the content becoming increasingly detailed. The HKMA joined the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) Special Data Dissemination Standard (SDDS) program for central banks in 1999. The HKMA also publishes the minutes of meetings of the Currency Board Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, as well as reports on the operation of the Currency Board system. Since 1996, the HKMA's website has featured banking supervision policies and guidelines.

The relationship between the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Legislative Council is crucial for enhancing accountability and transparency. The HKMA Governor has committed to providing three annual briefings to the Legislative Council's Financial Affairs Committee on the HKMA's operations and policies, and to address related inquiries. In addition, HKMA representatives regularly attend meetings of the Legislative Council's Committees and Subcommittees to elaborate on and discuss specific issues, as well as to support legislators in reviewing draft legislation.

# Surveillance measures

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority employs robust and effective internal and external monitoring mechanisms to ensure the maintenance of high standards of employee conduct, prudent risk management, and appropriate checks and balances. Internal and external audit functions provide independent assessments of the adequacy and effectiveness of these monitoring mechanisms.

# Code of Conduct

The Code of Conduct provides guidance on employees' ethical and legal responsibilities, ensuring that all employees at all levels meet the specified standards in their conduct.

# Internal Monitoring

# Operation Monitoring

As the first line of defense in risk management, all departments and branches are responsible for assessing the risks in their work processes and developing appropriate monitoring measures to ensure the stable daily operations of the HKMA.

# Institutional Risk Management

Risk management is also conducted at the institutional level. The Risk Committee, chaired by the Chief Executive of the HKMA, is one of the cornerstones of the institutional risk management framework.

The Risk Committee reviews and discusses potential and emerging risks identified by various departments, assesses whether the related monitoring measures and mitigation strategies are adequate, and determines appropriate follow-up actions.

# Internal Audit

The Internal Audit Department of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority independently assesses whether the governance procedures, risk management, and monitoring measures of different departments are sufficient and effective, and provides recommendations for improvement.

# External Audit

Under Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the financial statements of the Exchange Fund are audited by the Audit Commission of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government. The Audit Commission does not charge any fees for this service. The audited financial statements of the Exchange Fund are published in the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Annual Report.

# 經濟及金融環境

面對第五波新冠病毒疫情、金融狀況收緊及充滿挑戰的外圍環境，香港經濟在2022年顯著收縮。勞工市場持續一段時間轉差，其後逐步改善，而通脹則維持溫和。資產市場亦有所受壓。受惠於內地與香港全面通關，預計2023年香港經濟增長將由低位復甦。

# 經濟回顧

# 實體經濟活動

受本地及外圍環境各項不利因素拖累，香港經濟在2022年收縮3.5%（表1及圖1）。本地方面，由於香港爆發第五波新冠病毒疫情，私人消費在第1季急跌，其後受惠於社交距離措施逐步放寬及政府消費券計劃的刺激，私人消費再度錄得按季增長。在營商氣氛疲弱及金融狀況收緊下，整體投資支出較2021年顯著下跌。對外方面，隨着外部需求轉弱，加上內地與香港之間的跨境陸路貨運受阻，香港貨物出口下挫。服務輸出依然大致疲弱，部分反映訪港旅遊活動低迷，但其後隨着政府於9月下旬撤銷抵港強制檢疫要求，情況於第4季稍為改善。

# 通脹

本地通脹壓力於2022年稍升，但仍屬溫和。具體而言，按年基本通脹率逐步上升至12月2%的溫和水平，其中外圍能源及食品價格高企的影響部分被溫和的本地成本壓力所抵銷，尤其是偏軟的房屋租金（圖2）。此外，在經濟活動疲弱下，名義工資增長及商業樓宇租金持續偏軟，亦有助遏抑通脹。2022年全年合計，基本及整體通脹率分別為1.7%及1.9%。

# 勞工市場

疫情下勞工市場狀況在2022年初急速惡化，但隨後持續改善。失業率在4月升至5.4%的高位後，於12月顯著回落至3.5%（圖3），當中大多數行業的失業率均有所下降。總就業人數（圖3）及私營機構職位空缺回升，反映整體勞工需求逐步回復，惟總就業人數仍低於疫情前水平。名義工資和勞工收入的按年升幅亦略為加快。另一方面，與去年同期比較，勞動人口於12月略為減少1.5%，部分原因是勞動人口參與率輕微下跌。

# 股市

本港股市在2022年出現大幅波動。承接2021年的下行趨勢，恒生指數加速下跌，在2022年10月31日收報14,687點，是自2009年以來的最低水平（圖4）。股市顯著調整，最初是由市場對本地新冠病毒疫情、美國加息及俄烏局勢的憂慮加劇所觸發，其後由於環球金融狀況收緊及內地新冠病毒疫情導致環球經濟前景轉差，令股市調整幅度進一步擴大。股市在年內最後兩個月重拾一些上升動力，部分受到內地優化防疫抗疫措施所支持。恒生指數於年底收報19,781點，較2021年底顯著下跌15.5%，連續第三年下挫。

# 物業市場

在金融狀況收緊及經濟活動疲弱下，住宅物業市場亦有所受壓。樓價於2022年回落15%（圖4），成交量也大幅縮減39%至45,050宗，創下有紀錄以來的新低。儘管樓價下跌，置業負擔能力仍然偏緊。實際按揭利率於年內由約1.6厘上升至3.375至3.625厘，增加供樓人士的按揭供款負擔。非住宅物業市場亦進一步回軟。在空置率高企下，其價格有所回落，租金亦維持偏軟。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

受惠於內地與香港全面通關，預期2023年香港經濟增長將由低位復甦。儘管先進經濟體增長預期放緩將繼續拖累香港貨物出口，但內地經濟復甦及跨境陸路貨運限制撤銷，應能為本港經濟提供支持。內地與香港全面通關亦有望令香港入境旅遊及其他服務輸出顯著受惠，並提振本地營商氣氛及資本開支。私人消費亦將會在勞工市場轉強下進一步改善。政府預測2023年全年實質本地生產總值會顯著增長，介乎3.5至5.5%。然而，香港經濟增長前景仍受眾多風險及不明朗因素所影響，並很大程度上取決於美國聯邦儲備局政策利率走勢、全球增長前景、地緣政治局勢持續緊張以及本地入境旅遊的復甦步伐。

# 通脹及勞工市場

展望未來，預期本地通脹將輕微上升，但在各種因素互相抵銷下應保持溫和。儘管外圍價格應會維持高企，但由於部分主要經濟體的經濟活動轉弱及商品價格上行壓力緩和，外圍價格的上升動力或會進一步減弱。同樣地，隨着本地經濟復甦及勞工市場改善，本地成本壓力或會輕微上升，但房屋租金偏軟應繼續在一定程度上抵銷其影響。政府預測2023年全年合計的整體及基本通脹率分別為2.9%及2.5%。另一方面，勞工市場狀況有望隨着本地經濟活動復常而進一步改善。

# 銀行體系表現

香港銀行體系在2022年面對充滿挑戰的宏觀經濟環境，包括年初爆發第五波新冠病毒疫情、地緣政治局勢升溫，以及全球各大央行大幅度加息應對通脹上升等。面對各項挑戰，香港銀行應付裕如，資本及流動性狀況繼續保持充裕。年內銀行體系面對的信貸風險增加，但整體資產質素維持於健康水平。與此同時，利率上升促使銀行淨利息收入增加，但其正面影響因呆壞帳準備金增加及費用與佣金收入減少而被局部抵銷。整體而言，零售銀行盈利較2021年改善。

# 資產質素

銀行體系的特定分類貸款比率由2021年底的0.89%上升至2022年底的1.38%，逾期及經重組貸款比率於同期由0.56%升至0.85%（圖5）。中國內地相關貸款的特定分類貸款比率於2022年底為2.21%，亦較2021年底的0.89%上升。特定分類貸款比率上升，主要是由於部分內地房地產發展商的貸款評級被下調。儘管如此，銀行撥備充足，截至2022年底，銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率（即信貸撥備和特定分類貸款比率）約維持於80%。若將抵押品變現價值從呆壞帳餘額中扣除，銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率約140%。另一方面，2022年底住宅按揭貸款及信用卡貸款的拖欠比率仍然處於低位，分別為0.06%及0.23%（圖6）。

# 盈利走勢

銀行體系在2022年繼續錄得盈利。年內零售銀行的整體除稅前經營溢利上升19.0%（圖7）。盈利改善是受惠於淨利息收入（+34%）及外匯與衍生工具收入增加（+72%），但部分升幅被呆壞帳準備金增加（+151%）及費用與佣金收入減少（–19%）所抵銷。在加息環境下，淨息差由上一年的0.98%擴闊至2022年的1.31%（圖8）。年內市場波動增加，亦令銀行來自外匯及衍生工具業務的收入增加。呆壞帳準備金增加是由於須為新的特定分類貸款預留特殊準備金，而在金融市場表現疲弱下，費用及佣金收入減少。零售銀行成本與收入比率由2021年的54.7%，降至2022年的48.0%（圖9）。

# 資產負債表走勢

2022年銀行體系資產負債表擴大2.5%。資產上升是由於外匯及衍生工具持倉按市價計值增加。面對外圍不明朗因素及利率趨升，年內貸款需求減弱。相比2021年錄得3.8%的增幅，2022年貸款總額減少3.0%。其中在香港境外使用的貸款減少10.2%，貿易融資減少13.5%，在香港使用的貸款則稍增0.9%。中國內地相關貸款繼2021年增長3.7%後，於2022年減少4.4%。

在資產負債表的負債方面，銀行體系存款繼續錄得溫和增長。存款總額於2022年增加1.7%，相比2021年的增幅為4.6%。由於貸款總額減少而存款總額增加，整體貸存比率由2021年底的71.8%稍降至2022年底的68.5%（圖10）。

# 資本充足水平

銀行在2022年的資本狀況維持充裕。2022年底本地註冊認可機構的綜合總資本比率為20.1%，相比上一年為20.2%；一級資本比率為18.1%（圖11）。兩者均遠高於相關國際最低要求。《巴塞爾協定三》槓桿比率於2022年底為7.9%（圖12）。

# 流動性狀況

銀行體系的流動性狀況繼續維持穩健，成為在宏觀經濟環境不明朗因素加劇下的重要支柱。第1類機構的季度平均流動性覆蓋比率在2022年第4季為162.3%，第2類機構的季度平均流動性維持比率為63.2%（圖13）。銀行體系的主要資金來源仍然是客戶存款。於2022年底，第1類機構的穩定資金淨額比率及第2A類機構的核心資金比率分別為137.7%及155.7%（圖14）。以上所有4個比率均遠高於法定最低要求。

# Economic and Financial Environment

Faced with the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic, tightening financial conditions, and a challenging external environment, Hong Kong's economy contracted significantly in 2022. The labor market deteriorated for a period before gradually improving, while inflation remained moderate. Asset markets also faced pressure. Benefiting from the full resumption of travel between mainland China and Hong Kong, Hong Kong's economic growth is expected to recover from its low point in 2023.

# Economic Review

# Real Economic Activities

Hong Kong's economy contracted by 3.5% in 2022, dragged down by various adverse local and external factors (Table 1 and Figure 1). Locally, private consumption plummeted in the first quarter due to the outbreak of Hong Kong's fifth wave of the novel coronavirus. Private consumption then recorded a quarterly increase later, benefiting from the gradual relaxation of social distancing measures and the stimulus provided by the government's consumption voucher program. Under weak business sentiment and tightening financial conditions, overall investment expenditure fell significantly compared to 2021. Externally, Hong Kong's goods exports declined as external demand weakened and cross-border land freight between Hong Kong and mainland China was disrupted. Service exports remained largely weak, partly reflecting the subdued tourism activities in Hong Kong, but the situation improved slightly in the fourth quarter after the government lifted the mandatory quarantine requirement for arrivals in late September.
